column1: Þa on morgen gehyrdon þæt þæs cyninges þægnas þe him beæftan wæron þæt se cyning ofslægen wæs.
column2: Then in the morning the king's thanes that were behind heard that the king was slain.

column1: Ða ridon hie þyder ond his ealdorman osric ond wiferð his þegn ond þa men þe he him bæftan ær læfde
column2: Then they rode thither, Osric his alderman, and Wiferth his thane, and the men that he had left behind

column1: þone æþeling on þære byrig metton þær se cyning ofslægen læg
column2: they met the prince at the town, where the king lay slain.

column1: Her lædde beocca ealdorman Westsexna ælmessan and ælfredes cyninges to rome
column2: This year Alderman Beocca conducted the almsgiving of the West-Saxons and of King Alfred to Rome

column1: ælþelswið cwen, seo wæs ælfredes sweostor cyninges ond heo forðferde ond hire lic ligð æt pauian
column2: Queen Ethelswith, who was King Alfred's sister, died and her body lies at Pavia

column1: þyilcan geare æþered arcebiscop ond æþelwald ealdorman forðferdon on anum monðe
column2: The same year also Ethered, Archbishop of Canterbury and Alderman Ethelwold, died in one month.

column1: On þyssum geare næs nan færeld to rome butan twegen hleaperas ælfred cyning sende mid gewritum
column2: This year there was not any journey to Rome, except that King Alfred sent two messengers with letters

column1: Þu fæder ure ðe eart on heofonum
column2: You, our father who are in heaven

column1: Sy þin nama gehalgod
column2: hallowed be thy name

column1: Gecume þin rice
column2: Thy kingdom come

column1: Si þin willa swa on heaofonum ond eac on eorðan
column2: Thy will be done on earth as it is in heaven

column1: Syle us todæg urne dæghwomlican hlaf
column2: Give us this day our daily bread

column2: forgive us our sins

column1: Swa swa we forgifað þam þe wið us agiltað

column1: ne læt þu na us on costnunge

column1: Ac alys us fram yfele

column1: Si hit swa

column1: genim oxna lyb niþeweard gecnuwa wel wið wætre.  .
Wiþ sarum weolorum gesmire mid hunige þa weoloras genim þonne æges felman bescead mid pipore lege on.
Wiþ wouum muþe genim ompran ond ealdne swines rysle wyrc to sealfe sete on þone won dæl.
wiþ þon sceal eoforfearn eac swa ond gyþrifan wyl on meolce sup þonne ond gebeþe mid.
bisceopwyrt aterlaþe niðewearde ond clatan wyl on ealað.
, take [the] netherward [part of] oxna lyb, pound it well with water (), .
For sore lips, smear the lips with honey, then take the membrane of an egg, sprinkle with pepper and lay [it] on.
For a rough mouth take dock and old fat of a pig, make into a salve, set on the rough part.
for that [one] should boil polypody and also likewise corncockle in milk, then sip and bathe with [it].
, boil bishopwort, the lower part of black nightshade, and burdock in ale.
